assetIdentification.assetDescription: Control cabin climate through IVI system

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that HVAC control commands cannot be maliciously modified or spoofed
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Prevent unauthorized entities from manipulating cabin climate settings

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that climate control functionality remains available to legitimate users
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Maintain essential climate control functions during vehicle operation

threatScenarios.title: Spoofed HVAC temperature command via CAN bus
threatScenarios.description: An attacker gains access to the vehicle's CAN bus and injects spoofed HVAC temperature commands that appear to come from the IVI system, causing the cabin temperature to suddenly change to extreme settings
preconditions: Attacker has physical or remote access to vehicle CAN bus
Current CAN implementation lacks robust message authentication
HVAC ECU accepts temperature control commands from IVI without strong validation

vulnerabilities.description: HVAC control CAN messages lack strong authentication
Temperature command checksum can be bypassed
vulnerabilities.cweReference: CWE-354: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value

vulnerabilities.description: Lack of plausibility checks for temperature commands

attackSteps.description: Identify HVAC temperature control CAN ID
attackSteps.technique: Bus monitoring followed by message replay or generation
Calculate valid checksum for injected message
Set temperature data bytes with extreme values

attackPaths.attackFlow: The attacker first identifies the CAN message responsible for temperature control, then constructs a valid message with an extreme temperature setting and the correct checksum. When injected onto the bus, this message is accepted by the HVAC ECU as legitimate, resulting in a sudden extreme temperature change. The attacker can time this command to be most effective - typically while the vehicle is in motion to maximize driver distraction.

elapsedTime.justification: Requires several days to analyze CAN messages and develop appropriate injection technique

expertise.justification: Requires specialized knowledge of automotive networks and protocols

knowledgeOfItem.justification: Requires internal details about message structure and validation mechanisms

windowOfOpportunity.justification: Attack can be performed whenever attacker has access to the vehicle

equipment.justification: Requires specialized hardware for CAN bus interfacing and custom software for message generation

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: The sum of individual scores indicates high attack feasibility

threatScenarios.title: Denial of Service attack on HVAC defogger function
threatScenarios.description: An attacker intercepts and blocks defogger activation commands from the IVI to the HVAC ECU, preventing the windshield defogger from operating during cold/humid conditions
preconditions: Attacker has physical or remote access to vehicle CAN bus
Defogger command lacks sufficient authentication or integrity protection
No redundant path for critical defogger activation

vulnerabilities.cweReference: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity

vulnerabilities.description: No fallback mechanism for defogging in case of command failure
vulnerabilities.cweReference: CWE-755: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions

vulnerabilities.description: Single communication path for critical defogger commands

attackSteps.technique: Bus monitoring to identify defogger-related messages
Configure CAN interface to intercept and drop specific messages
Deploy attack when environment sensors detect conditions where defogging would be needed
prerequisites: Knowledge of vehicle environmental data on CAN bus

attackPaths.attackFlow: The attacker identifies the CAN messages used for defogger activation through passive monitoring. Using specialized hardware, they selectively block or corrupt these specific messages while allowing other HVAC commands to pass normally. This makes the attack harder to detect since only the defogger function is impaired. The attack is most effective during cold/humid conditions when the defogger would normally be activated.

elapsedTime.justification: Requires time to identify specific defogger messages and create selective blocking mechanism

expertise.justification: Requires specialized knowledge of automotive networks and selective message blocking

knowledgeOfItem.justification: Requires knowledge of defogger message format but not implementation details

windowOfOpportunity.justification: Attack requires specific weather conditions to be most effective

equipment.justification: Requires CAN interface hardware with message filtering capabilities

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: The sum of individual scores indicates medium attack feasibility

threatScenarios.title: Rapid oscillation attack on HVAC system
threatScenarios.description: An attacker injects a sequence of rapidly changing temperature and fan speed commands to cause the HVAC system to oscillate erratically, creating noise and temperature fluctuations that distract the driver
preconditions: Attacker has physical or remote access to vehicle CAN bus
HVAC system lacks rate limiting for control commands
No detection mechanism for abnormal command patterns
threatScenarios.attackVector: CAN message injection with rapid sequence

vulnerabilities.description: HVAC system accepts commands without rate limiting
vulnerabilities.cweReference: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

vulnerabilities.description: Lack of anomaly detection for command sequences
vulnerabilities.cweReference: CWE-754: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions

vulnerabilities.description: HVAC ECU unable to filter implausible command sequences

attackSteps.description: Identify temperature and fan control CAN IDs
attackSteps.technique: Bus monitoring to identify climate control messages

attackSteps.description: Develop script for rapid command generation
attackSteps.technique: Create automated script to generate alternating extreme settings

attackSteps.description: Deploy attack with maximum oscillation frequency
attackSteps.technique: Tune command frequency to maximize audible and temperature variations
prerequisites: Understanding of HVAC system response characteristics

attackPaths.attackFlow: The attacker identifies the CAN messages used for temperature and fan control through passive monitoring. They then develop an automated script that generates a rapid sequence of alternating commands (hot/cold temperature, high/low fan speed). When injected onto the CAN bus, these commands cause the HVAC system to continuously fluctuate, creating distracting noise from the fan and noticeable temperature changes in the cabin.

elapsedTime.justification: Once CAN message formats are known, creating oscillation script is relatively quick

expertise.justification: Requires working knowledge of CAN bus protocol but not deep expertise

knowledgeOfItem.justification: Requires knowledge of HVAC message formats but not implementation details

windowOfOpportunity.justification: Attack can be performed whenever attacker has access to the vehicle

equipment.justification: Requires common CAN bus interface tools available to researchers

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: The sum of individual scores indicates very high attack feasibility

relatedStandards.description: Threat analysis and risk assessment methods

relatedRequirements.description: The IVI system shall implement message authentication for all TEMP_Control_Command messages using vehicle-specific keys
The IVI system shall implement redundant validation for temperature values (16°C to 30°C)
The IVI system shall maintain HVAC functionality after experiencing up to 10 consecutive error events in the CAN communication
The IVI system shall maintain separate security domains for entertainment functions and vehicle control functions including HVAC controls

keyTerms.Checksum: Value used to verify data integrity

contentSummary: Asset: Function: Control cabin climate through IVI system. Cyber‑security properties: Integrity and Availability. Damage scenarios: DA-HVAC-01, DA-HVAC-02, DA-HVAC-03. Threat scenarios: TS-HVAC-01 – Spoofed HVAC temperature command via CAN bus, TS-HVAC-02 – Denial of Service attack on HVAC defogger function, TS-HVAC-03 – Rapid oscillation attack on HVAC system. Attack feasibility → TS-HVAC-01: High (10), TS-HVAC-02: Medium (9), TS-HVAC-03: Very High (4).
